bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, October 21, 1940

div1.p: Hench thanks Webster for his help in finding the location of Camp Lazear and in identifying the "false camp." Hench discusses his plans to honor the site of Lazear's death.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, October 21, 1940
div1.opener:
October 21, 1940
Mr. Royal S. Webster
Divisional Engineer
Havana Railroad
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Webster:
div1.p:
I certainly appreciate your further help in the
matter of the location of Camp Lazear, and of the identity
of the “false camp”. Your maps have been a great help. It
is my pleasure to acknowledge this help in the address which
I am giving this Saturday at the dedication of the Lazear
Memorial at Washington and Jefferson College. I will try to
send you a draft of my paper shortly after my return. You
may have heard that we have found one of the old buildings
used for the experiments and I hope to restore this and with
the help of friends, present it to the Cuban government,
possibly for placement at the false camp site, which, after all,
is the site of Lazear's death. You know that the government
plans to build quite a Lazear Memorial Institute there. It
occurs to me to suggest that at least a small section of the
railroad track be allowed to remain at that spot. This track
is an important land mark to the identity of the camp, the former
hospital, and the site of Lazear's death, as you will see when
I send you my manuscript. The track is mentioned frequently in
General Truby's autobiography, eventually to be published. I
understand that the track is being abandoned and may some day be
torn up. I suggest maintaining a section two or three blocks in
length and that perhaps the eventual construction of a small
memorial bridge from the Military Hospital grounds over to or near
the false camp site be undertaken. This bridge really did exist.
General Kean says it was built by the quartermaster corps on their
own initiative, as a matter of convenience.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
